documentation.title: React Server Components & Suspense (v18+)
documentation.summary: Server Components render on the server only. Client Components render on the client. This split enables better performance and smaller client bundles.
bestPractices: Components are Server Components by default in Next.js App Router
Add 'use client' at the top of file to make it a Client Component
Keep 'use client' boundary as low as possible in the component tree
Server Components can import Client Components, but NOT vice versa
Pass Server Component data as props to Client Components
Use Suspense for loading states: `<Suspense fallback={<Loading />}><AsyncComponent /></Suspense>`
Server Actions use 'use server' directive for server-side mutations
async/await can be used directly in Server Components
Use React.lazy() for code splitting Client Components
commonMistakes: Using hooks (useState, useEffect) in Server Components — they only work in Client Components
Using browser APIs (window, document, localStorage) in Server Components
Adding 'use client' unnecessarily — this increases the client bundle size
Importing a Server Component into a Client Component — pass as children prop instead
Not using Suspense boundaries for async operations
Passing non-serializable props (functions, classes) from Server to Client Components
